message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0
Paper Abstract: The SCIP Optimization Suite provides a collection of software packages for mathematical optimization, centered around the constraint integer programming (CIP) framework SCIP. This report discusses the enhancements and extensions included in the SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0. The updates in SCIP 9.0 include improved symmetry handling, additions and improvements of nonlinear handlers and primal heuristics, a new cut generator and two new cut selection schemes, a new branching rule, a new LP interface, and several bug fixes. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also features new Rust and C++ interfaces for SCIP, new Python interface for SoPlex, along with enhancements to existing interfaces. The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0 also includes new and improved features in the LP solver SoPlex, the presolving library PaPILO, the parallel framework UG, the decomposition framework GCG, and the SCIP extension SCIP-SDP. These additions and enhancements have resulted in an overall performance improvement of SCIP in terms of solving time, number of nodes in the branch-and-bound tree, as well as the reliability of the solver.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about presolving algorithm optimization:

The search results provide general information about mathematical optimization, but don't contain specific details about **presolving algorithms** specifically. However, I can provide some context about optimization techniques:

The search results discuss various optimization methods and algorithms, including:

- Line searches and trust regions are methods used to ensure convergence in optimization
- Branch-and-bound, branch-and-cut, dynamic programming, and tabu search are widely applicable approaches for combinatorial optimization
- The simplex algorithm solves linear programming problems by constructing a feasible solution and walking along a path to vertices with non-decreasing objective function values

**Presolving** is a specific preprocessing technique used in optimization solvers (particularly in integer and linear programming) that simplifies problems before the main solving algorithm runs, but the search results don't contain detailed information about presolving specifically. 

If you're looking for detailed information about presolving algorithms, you may want to search for more specialized resources on integer linear programming, mixed-integer programming solvers (like CPLEX, GUROBI, or open-source solvers), or academic papers focused specifically on presolving techniques.

Links: [{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Concurrent constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concurrent_constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Category:Constraint programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Constraint_programming_languages"},{"title":"Talk:Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction"},{"title":"Constraint Handling Rules - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_Handling_Rules"},{"title":"Active-set method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active-set_method"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"}]

Here are the search results for Constraint Programming:

## Overview

Constraint programming (CP) is a paradigm for solving combinatorial problems that draws on a wide range of techniques from artificial intelligence, computer science, and operations research.(no content)In constraint programming, users declaratively state the constraints on the feasible solutions for a set of decision variables.

## Key Concepts

Constraints differ from the common primitives of imperative programming languages in that they do not specify a step or sequence of steps to execute, but rather the properties of a solution to be found.(no content)The constraint programming approach is to search for a state of the world in which a large number of constraints are satisfied at the same time. A problem is typically stated as a state of the world containing a number of unknown variables. The constraint program searches for values for all the variables.

## Solution Methods

This typically draws upon standard methods like chronological backtracking and constraint propagation, but may use customized code like a problem-specific branching heuristic.(no content)Constraint propagation works by reducing domains of variables, strengthening constraints, or creating new ones.

## Implementation Approaches

Constraint programming takes its root from and can be expressed in the form of constraint logic programming, which embeds constraints into a logic program. This variant of logic programming is due to Jaffar and Lassez, who extended in 1987 a specific class of constraints that were introduced in Prolog II.(no content)Mostly, constraints are implemented in imperative languages via constraint solving toolkits, which are separate libraries for an existing imperative language.

Links: [{"title":"Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Branch and price - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_price"},{"title":"Joint compatibility branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_compatibility_branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Travelling salesman problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Branch and bound - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Branch_and_bound"},{"title":"Talk:Uniform-cost search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uniform-cost_search"},{"title":"B* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B*"},{"title":"Shifting bottleneck heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shifting_bottleneck_heuristic"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Branch and Bound algorithm:

## Overview

Branch-and-bound is a method for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller subproblems and using a bounding function to eliminate subproblems that cannot contain the optimal solution.(no content)It is an algorithm design paradigm for discrete and combinatorial optimization problems, as well as mathematical optimization.

## How It Works

A branch-and-bound algorithm consists of a systematic enumeration of candidate solutions by means of state-space search: the set of candidate solutions is thought of as forming a rooted tree with the full set at the root. The algorithm explores branches of this tree, which represent subsets of the solution set. Before enumerating the candidate solutions of a branch, the branch is checked against upper and lower estimated bounds on the optimal solution, and is discarded if it cannot produce a better solution than the best one found so far by the algorithm.

## Key Principle

To improve on the performance of brute-force search, a B&B algorithm keeps track of bounds on the minimum that it is trying to find, and uses these bounds to "prune" the search space, eliminating candidate solutions that it can prove will not contain an optimal solution.

## History

The method was first proposed by Ailsa Land and Alison Doig whilst carrying out research at the London School of Economics sponsored by British Petroleum in 1960 for discrete programming, and has become the most commonly used tool for solving NP-hard optimization problems.

## Applications

Branch and bound is widely used for solving complex optimization problems, including the traveling salesman problem, integer linear programming, and various combinatorial optimization challenges.

Links: [{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Fundamental theorem of linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_linear_programming"},{"title":"Basic solution (linear programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_solution_(linear_programming)"},{"title":"Multi-objective linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_linear_programming"},{"title":"GNU Linear Programming Kit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_Linear_Programming_Kit"},{"title":"Successive linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Successive_linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear genetic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_genetic_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming decoding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_decoding"},{"title":"Sequential linear-quadratic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_linear-quadratic_programming"}]

## Linear Programming Overview

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.(no content)More formally, linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

### Key Concepts

Its feasible region is a convex polytope, which is a set defined as the intersection of finitely many half spaces, each of which is defined by a linear inequality. Its objective function is a real-valued affine (linear) function defined on this polytope. A linear programming algorithm finds a point in the polytope where this function has the largest (or smallest) value if such a point exists.

### Practical Applications

Industries that use linear programming models include transportation, energy, telecommunications, and manufacturing. It has proven useful in modeling diverse types of problems in planning, routing, scheduling, assignment, and design.

### Historical Development

In the late 1930s, Soviet mathematician Leonid Kantorovich and American economist Wassily Leontief independently delved into the practical applications of linear programming. Kantorovich focused on manufacturing schedules, while Leontief explored economic applications.(no content)The turning point came during World War II when linear programming emerged as a vital tool. It found extensive use in addressing complex wartime challenges, including transportation logistics, scheduling, and resource allocation.(no content)From 1946 to 1947 George B. Dantzig independently developed general linear programming formulation to use for planning problems in the US Air Force. In 1947, Dantzig also invented the simplex method that, for the first time efficiently, tackled the linear programming problem in most cases.

Links: [{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Fundamental theorem of linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_linear_programming"},{"title":"Basic solution (linear programming) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_solution_(linear_programming)"},{"title":"Multi-objective linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_linear_programming"},{"title":"GNU Linear Programming Kit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_Linear_Programming_Kit"},{"title":"Successive linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Successive_linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear genetic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_genetic_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming decoding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_decoding"},{"title":"Sequential linear-quadratic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_linear-quadratic_programming"}]

## Linear Programming Overview

Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.(no content)More formally, linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

### Key Concepts

Its feasible region is a convex polytope, which is a set defined as the intersection of finitely many half spaces, each of which is defined by a linear inequality. Its objective function is a real-valued affine (linear) function defined on this polytope. A linear programming algorithm finds a point in the polytope where this function has the largest (or smallest) value if such a point exists.

### Practical Applications

Industries that use linear programming models include transportation, energy, telecommunications, and manufacturing. It has proven useful in modeling diverse types of problems in planning, routing, scheduling, assignment, and design.

### Historical Development

In the late 1930s, Soviet mathematician Leonid Kantorovich and American economist Wassily Leontief independently delved into the practical applications of linear programming. Kantorovich focused on manufacturing schedules, while Leontief explored economic applications.(no content)The turning point came during World War II when linear programming emerged as a vital tool. It found extensive use in addressing complex wartime challenges, including transportation logistics, scheduling, and resource allocation.(no content)From 1946 to 1947 George B. Dantzig independently developed general linear programming formulation to use for planning problems in the US Air Force. In 1947, Dantzig also invented the simplex method that, for the first time efficiently, tackled the linear programming problem in most cases.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Category:Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Eight queens puzzle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eight_queens_puzzle"},{"title":"Anomaly matching condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomaly_matching_condition"},{"title":"Complexity of constraint satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complexity_of_constraint_satisfaction"},{"title":"Flow network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flow_network"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Constraint satisfaction problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_satisfaction_problem"},{"title":"Constraint (computer-aided design) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_(computer-aided_design)"}]

Here are the search results for "Symmetry breaking constraint programming":

## Overview

Symmetry-breaking constraints is a method in combinatorial optimization that can be used to take advantage of symmetries in many constraint satisfaction and optimization problems, by adding constraints that eliminate symmetries and reduce the search space size.

## Constraint Programming Context

Constraint programming is a paradigm for solving combinatorial problems that draws on a wide range of techniques from artificial intelligence, computer science, and operations research. In constraint programming, users declaratively state the constraints on the feasible solutions for a set of decision variables.(no content)Constraint satisfaction problems often exhibit high complexity, requiring a combination of heuristics and combinatorial search methods to be solved in a reasonable time. Constraint programming is the field of research that specifically focuses on tackling these kinds of problems.

## Solving CSPs

Constraint satisfaction problems on finite domains are typically solved using a form of search. The most used techniques are variants of backtracking, constraint propagation, and local search.

The symmetry-breaking constraints approach fits within this broader framework as a technique to improve the efficiency of constraint problem solving by reducing unnecessary exploration of symmetric solutions.

Web search results for query: "Heuristic algorithm optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Heuristic (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Metaheuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaheuristic"},{"title":"Heuristic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heuristic"},{"title":"Category:Heuristic algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Heuristic_algorithms"},{"title":"Greedy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greedy_algorithm"},{"title":"Table of metaheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_of_metaheuristics"},{"title":"Matheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matheuristics"},{"title":"List of metaphor-based metaheuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_metaphor-based_metaheuristics"},{"title":"Local search (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)"},{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"}]

Here are the search results for "Heuristic algorithm optimization":

## Overview

A heuristic is any approach to problem solving that employs a pragmatic method that is not fully optimized, perfected, or rationalized, but is nevertheless "good enough" as an approximation or attribute substitution.(no content)Where finding an optimal solution is impossible or impractical, heuristic methods can be used to speed up the process of finding a satisfactory solution.

## Role in Optimization

Heuristics may produce results by themselves, or they may be used in conjunction with optimization algorithms to improve their efficiency (e.g., they may be used to generate good seed values).(no content)Results about NP-hardness in theoretical computer science make heuristics the only viable option for a variety of complex optimization problems that need to be routinely solved in real-world applications.

## Metaheuristics

In computer science and mathematical optimization, a metaheuristic is a higher-level procedure or heuristic designed to find, generate, tune, or select a heuristic (partial search algorithm) that may provide a sufficiently good solution to an optimization problem or a machine learning problem, especially with incomplete or imperfect information or limited computation capacity.(no content)Metaheuristics often provide good solutions with less computational effort than approximation methods, iterative methods, or simple heuristics. Common metaheuristic approaches include simulated annealing, tabu search, iterated local search, variable neighborhood search, GRASP, ant colony optimization, evolutionary computation such as genetic algorithms, particle swarm optimization, and bacterial foraging algorithms.

## Local Search Methods

In computer science, local search is a heuristic method for solving computationally hard optimization problems.(no content)A local search algorithm starts from a candidate solution and then iteratively moves to a neighboring solution; a neighborhood being the set of all potential solutions that differ from the current solution by the minimal possible extent.

Links: [{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"COIN-OR - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COIN-OR"},{"title":"Discrete optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_optimization"},{"title":"MINTO - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MINTO"},{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Randomized rounding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_rounding"},{"title":"OR-Tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OR-Tools"},{"title":"Quadratically constrained quadratic program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratically_constrained_quadratic_program"}]

## Integer Programming

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Integer Programming:

### Definition

An integer programming problem is a mathematical optimization or feasibility program in which some or all of the variables are restricted to be integers.(no content)In many settings the term refers to integer linear programming (ILP), in which the objective function and the constraints (other than the integer constraints) are linear.

### Key Variations

- **Integer Linear Programming (ILP):** All variables must be integers
- **Binary Integer Programming:** 0–1 integer programming or binary integer programming (BIP) is the special case of integer programming where variables are required to be 0 or 1 (rather than arbitrary integers).
- **Mixed Integer Programming:** If some decision variables are not discrete, the problem is known as a mixed-integer programming problem.

### Computational Complexity

Integer programming is NP-complete (the difficult part is showing the NP membership).(no content)In contrast to linear programming, which can be solved efficiently in the worst case, integer programming problems are in many practical situations (those with bounded variables) NP-hard.

### Applications

Integer programming has numerous practical applications, including:
- Mixed-integer programming has many applications in industrial productions, including job-shop modelling.
- These problems involve service and vehicle scheduling in transportation networks. For example, a problem may involve assigning buses or subways to individual routes so that a timetable can be met.
- The task of frequency planning in GSM mobile networks involves distributing available frequencies across the antennas. This problem can be formulated as an integer linear program.

### Solution Methods

Common approaches include cutting-plane methods, branch-and-bound algorithms, and linear programming relaxation techniques to find approximate or exact solutions.

Links: [{"title":"Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Branch and cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_and_cut"},{"title":"Linear programming relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming_relaxation"},{"title":"Talk:Cutting-plane method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Cutting-plane_method"},{"title":"Global optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_optimization"},{"title":"Guillotine cutting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guillotine_cutting"},{"title":"Maximum cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxcut"},{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Category:Optimization algorithms and methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Optimization_algorithms_and_methods"},{"title":"Cutting stock problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutting_stock_problem"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the cutting-plane method in optimization:

## Overview

The cutting-plane method is any of a variety of optimization methods that iteratively refine a feasible set or objective function by means of linear inequalities, termed cuts.

## Applications

Such procedures are commonly used to find integer solutions to mixed integer linear programming (MILP) problems, as well as to solve general, not necessarily differentiable convex optimization problems.

## How It Works for Integer Programming

Cutting plane methods for MILP work by solving a non-integer linear program, the linear relaxation of the given integer program. The process follows these steps:

1. The obtained optimum is tested for being an integer solution. If it is not, there is guaranteed to exist a linear inequality that separates the optimum from the convex hull of the true feasible set.

2. Such an inequality is a cut. A cut can be added to the relaxed linear program.

3. This process is repeated until an optimal integer solution is found.

## Applications to Convex Optimization

Cutting-plane methods for general convex continuous optimization and variants are known under various names: Kelley's method, Kelley–Cheney–Goldstein method, and bundle methods. They are popularly used for non-differentiable convex minimization, where a convex objective function and its subgradient can be evaluated efficiently but usual gradient methods for differentiable optimization can not be used.

## Historical Development

Cutting planes were proposed by Ralph Gomory in the 1950s as a method for solving integer programming and mixed-integer programming problems. However, most experts, including Gomory himself, considered them to be impractical due to numerical instability, as well as ineffective because many rounds of cuts were needed to make progress towards the solution.(no content)Things turned around when in the mid-1990s Gérard Cornuéjols and co-workers showed them to be very effective in combination with branch-and-bound (called branch-and-cut) and ways to overcome numerical instabilities.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of "The SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0" paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper describes enhancements and extensions to the SCIP Optimization Suite 9.0, introducing new features, interfaces, and improvements.

**Extracted Triples:** 7 entities were identified and validated

### Key Technologies and Methods Identified:

1. **Constraint programming** (concept) - Used as the foundational paradigm for SCIP
2. **Integer programming** (concept) - The core optimization problem type solved by SCIP
3. **Linear programming** (concept) - Used for relaxations in the branch-and-bound framework
4. **Branch and bound** (method) - The fundamental algorithm at the core of SCIP
5. **Cutting-plane method** (method) - New cut generators and selection schemes in v9.0
6. **Heuristic (computer science)** (method) - Improvements to primal heuristics
7. **Symmetry-breaking constraints** (method) - Improved symmetry handling in v9.0

All triples have been:
- ✅ Mapped to correct Wikipedia articles
- ✅ Classified with appropriate entity types
- ✅ Labeled with correct relations (uses/proposes)
- ✅ Given relevance explanations
- ✅ Validated against the JSON schema

The validation script confirmed all checks passed successfully!

- [Linear programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming)
